content.description:
Short hand crack a few feet to the right of Rexrodes Inn that ends below the top of the formation.  The paper guidebook says 5.10c but with crack gloves it felt the same difficulty as Rexrodes Inn.

Can set up a gear anchor from the top (like Rexrodes Inn) with some very long slings.  The hanger-less bolts at the top of Rexrodes would be helpful for this.
content.location: A few feet to the right of Rexrodes Inn.  Leaves the ground at the same spot as that climb.

content.description: As you move right past Cat Crack (and some slab climbing) you can climb up the right side of the crag.  Awkward short lieback to sharp jams to tiny OW topout.  What's not to love?

Cool jams in a corner.  This is the first climb I came to after beginning to climb out of the canyon and up the slope towards the main crag.  You can see the boulder from the guardrail before you head down the trail, obvious dihedral faces south.

See area description for more detailed approach info.

Continue past Rexrode Inn on the west side, heading north up the hill for about 50 yards or so.  You'll come to an obvious drop-off that faces north.  This is the main crag.

As you drop down, on your right is this climb (also facing north).  Wide hands to tight hands/fingers, a cool broulder problem that could be TR/sewed up if you felt like it.  Steep and really fun, landing is reasonable.  Not sure on the name, stronger men than I think it's 5.10.

Having walked past this numerous times and never seeing chalk, it finally piqued my interest the other day.  It climbs more like a boulder problem than a true crack, using edges, smears, one small tips lock and a discrete yet rewarding arête pinch.  I had to brush lichen from a critical foot with my beta. An exciting throw for the lip then mantle and finish with the tall top crack section.  This climb is very worthwhile and should be on your list.

Name and FA info is unknown.
content.location: On the approach trail, before reaching Cat Crack area, the climb is on your left... hard to miss.

content.description: Long slot to the right of Cat Crack; can't miss it. Chimney to offwidth to hands with a couple of high steps thrown in for good measure. Small crimps help out in the crux but footwork is key. Climbs better than it looks!
content.protection:
Looks like it would take some gear but I'm not sure I'd trust the flake you'd be placing some of it behind.

For TR, there are two bolts up top that are apparently for a slab that one can use with a redirect.

content.description:
Sweet tips crack with delicate feet.  Not sure on the rating, but I think it's correct.  Head north about 50 yards past Rexrode Inn on the west side to the main crag.  You can drop down to the right or left when you reach a north-facing dropoff.  Anchor bolts for this and other climbs are obvious.  This is my new favorite finger crack on the hill.

Didn't realize how long this climb was - tried to do this with my 25 meter (82 foot) rope...not happening.  Probably need 100 ft to comfortably TR from the bolts with a ground belay.
content.protection: Looks like thin gear would do it - bolted anchor and walkoff make for an easy TR setup.

content.description: This is a worthy addition to the area on MP.  Starts with unassumingly small crimps on a horizontal seam.  Use a good left toe and throw for a powerful left hand gaston in a flaring crack and follow it to the top.  (First time I caught that hold, some rock broke loose.  I sent it a few times that day and it felt solid each time thereafter.)
content.location: The large slab above Cat Crack.
